{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3161032,"name":"Elmer Lee (head mentor)","username":"sthump","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sthump/{size}/211548_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-09T18:26:56.756Z","cooked":"

Over last weekend at Jackson FIM, we noticed that our auton would twitch the robot about 2 degrees at the very start. We thought it was code but despite a changes in when we set gyro angle or set our target angle, (we have a PID auto turn algorithm always running in periodic) the twitch still happened. We come back home and run the exact same code and there is no twitch.

You can see an example of the twitch in our finals match here:

we are red in the middle position, 9312.

This is last night running the same exact code:

Code is in LabVIEW. Drive system is SDS MK4i. Drives are controls by open loop percent vbus in the falcons.

My question is could there be something in the interaction with the FMS, a delay or something, that would cause the PID auto turn to twitch. The PID has only P and D gains. No I gain to build up on. Just wondering if anyone has run into performance differences when connected to the field that might have lead to this twitch.

Thanks

Stupid, stupid question. You aren’t by any chance tweaking the robot after a gyro stabilizes when on the field, are you? Say, kicking it about 2 degrees when lining up?

If so, that would explain it every time. You’ll want a way to tell the gyro to rezero after you’ve finished placing the robot.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-03-09T20:17:19.282Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":85,"readers_count":84,"score":22.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":429591,"topic_slug":"robot-twitch-in-auton-only-at-competition","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/robot-twitch-in-auton-only-at-competition/429591/2","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3161177,"name":"Elmer Lee (head mentor)","username":"sthump","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sthump/{size}/211548_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-09T20:19:52.808Z","cooked":"

We specifically turn on the robot as the last thing we do prior to leaving the field. I don’t believe that’s the case.

It is possible that the gyro could have drifted. But we specifically call a gyro reset at the beginning of auton. We don’t do a wait though to make sure that’s gone thru before we allow movement.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-03-09T21:44:38.798Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":77,"readers_count":76,"score":20.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":429591,"topic_slug":"robot-twitch-in-auton-only-at-competition","display_username":"Elmer Lee (head mentor)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":4212,"username":"EricH","name":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29757,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Head Mentor, 9312(FRC) 14353(FTC)"},"post_url":"/t/robot-twitch-in-auton-only-at-competition/429591/3","custom_user_title":"Head Mentor, 9312(FRC) 14353(FTC)","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3161301,"name":"Crystal","username":"CIM","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cim/{size}/3861_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-09T21:53:12.828Z","cooked":"
sthump:

But we specifically call a gyro reset at the beginning of auton.

Recalibrating the gyro takes a few seconds. If you call this at the beginning of auto, and then move immediately, you’ll mess it up.

One solution to this is to have your robot’s gyro calibrate at the press of a button on your OI. Your robot is allowed to read things like dashboard settings / buttons during Disabled. If you can ensure calibration happens during Disabled, then at the start of auton you’ll be good to go.

We are not recalibrating gyro I think. We are just resetting the gyro angle. I’m assuming setting the gyro angle doesn’t force it to recalibrate correct?
